source.620c0e99:
plt.figure(figsize=(15,5))

plt.subplot(1,2,1)
plt.hist(data['Horizontal_Distance_To_Roadways'], color='cyan')
plt.hist(data['Horizontal_Distance_To_Fire_Points'], color='orange',alpha=0.7)
plt.legend('upper right' , labels = ['Horizontal_Distance_To_Roadways', 'Horizontal_Distance_To_Fire_Points'])
plt.xlabel("Distance")

plt.subplot(1,2,2)
plt.hist(data['Horizontal_Distance_To_Hydrology'], color='green')
plt.hist(data['Vertical_Distance_To_Hydrology'], color='maroon', alpha=0.7)
plt.legend('upper right' , labels = ['Horizontal_Distance_To_Hydrology', 'Vertical_Distance_To_Hydrology'])
plt.xlabel("Distance")

source.2912ca2a:
plt.figure(figsize=(13,15))
plt.subplots_adjust(hspace=0.5)


plt.subplot(3,2,1)
a1 = sn.barplot(x='Cover_Type', y='Elevation', data=data)
a1.set_xticklabels(a1.get_xticklabels(), rotation=15)

plt.subplot(3,2,3)
a2 = sn.barplot(x='Cover_Type', y='Aspect', data=data)
a2.set_xticklabels(a2.get_xticklabels(), rotation=15);


plt.subplot(3,2,5)
a3 = sn.barplot(x='Cover_Type', y='Slope', data=data)
a3.set_xticklabels(a3.get_xticklabels(), rotation=15);


plt.subplot(3,2,2)
a4 = sn.boxplot(x='Cover_Type', y='Elevation', data=data)
a4.set_xticklabels(a4.get_xticklabels(), rotation=15);

plt.subplot(3,2,4)
a5 = sn.boxplot(x='Cover_Type', y='Aspect', data=data)
a5.set_xticklabels(a5.get_xticklabels(), rotation=15);

plt.subplot(3,2,6)
a6 = sn.boxplot(x='Cover_Type', y='Slope', data=data)
a6.set_xticklabels(a6.get_xticklabels(), rotation=15);

b1.set_xticklabels(b1.get_xticklabels(), rotation=15);


plt.subplot(2,2,2)
b2 = sn.violinplot(x='Cover_Type', y='Vertical_Distance_To_Hydrology', data=data)
b2.set_xticklabels(b2.get_xticklabels(), rotation=15);


plt.subplot(2,2,3)
b3 = sn.violinplot(x='Cover_Type', y='Horizontal_Distance_To_Roadways', data=data)
b3.set_xticklabels(b3.get_xticklabels(), rotation=15);


plt.subplot(2,2,4)
b4 = sn.violinplot(x='Cover_Type', y='Horizontal_Distance_To_Fire_Points', data=data)
b4.set_xticklabels(b4.get_xticklabels(), rotation=15);

source.db317a5b:
### The wilderness areas are:

1 - Rawah Wilderness Area

2 - Neota Wilderness Area

3 - Comanche Peak Wilderness Area

4 - Cache la Poudre Wilderness Area
source.99f13117:
The count plot gives the quantitative representation of the cover type from each wilderness area. Each area has different cover types

Comanche peak has most variety of cover types

Cottonwood is only found in Cache la Poudre region

This plot also proves our above interpretation:
That Ponderosa pine, Douglas fir and Cottonwood belong to same wildnerness area where as the other cover types Aspen, Lodgepole pine, Spruce fir and Krummholz belong to different areas
source.3902787c:
### Data Description

The study area includes four wilderness areas located in the Roosevelt National Forest of northern Colorado. Each observation is a 30m x 30m patch. You are asked to predict an integer classification for the forest cover type. The seven types are:

1 - Spruce/Fir

2 - Lodgepole Pine

3 - Ponderosa Pine

4 - Cottonwood/Willow

5 - Aspen

6 - Douglas-fir

7 - Krummholz
source.3591cded:
There is variation in the cover type that are found in differet wilderness area

Comanche peak has most whereas as Neota has least cover types
source.2cb9a7c2:
The swarm plot for the hillshade variables show similar trend we cannot see any significant difference among the cover type

We can leave this features for further analysis as all cover types are performing in same manner
source.d9ec4bb4:
The soil type for each cover type is arranged is ascending order.

The soil type 10 is most common.

There are no obervation for soil type 7 and 15
source.a9d910b0:
The scatter and regression plot represent the relation between the selected features from the correlation plot.

The features with positive correlation value show positive relation that means if value of one field increase result in the increment of the related field. The feature with negative relation behaves in oposite manner.

The graphs confirms the interpretation that all cover type have same trends in the selected features.

As the cover types show no significant difference in these features therefore these related data fields are not relevent for our analysis
source.9b4e4aba: The distribution of hillshade at in the morning and afternoon is negaitively skewed whereas at noon time it is evenly distributed
source.dfd1db74:
Barplot(left) and boxplot(right) for each cover type

The bar graph show the varition in the feature elevation, aspect and slope for each cover type

The boxplot show that there is significant difference among the cover type for the elevation. For feature aspect and slope there is no signicant differnce among the group
source.b07727e7:
All variables related to distance show the skewed distribution

a) The distribution of horizontal distance from the the roadways and fire-point is similar. Most of the forest cover are within 3000 units away from the designated area

b) Most of the cover types are above the water level and within limit of 400 unit distance from water source
source.f5af88b0:
### Data Fields

Elevation - Elevation in meters

Aspect - Aspect in degrees azimuth

Slope - Slope in degrees

Horizontal_Distance_To_Hydrology - Horz Dist to nearest surface water features

Vertical_Distance_To_Hydrology - Vert Dist to nearest surface water features

Horizontal_Distance_To_Roadways - Horz Dist to nearest roadway

Hillshade_9am (0 to 255 index) - Hillshade index at 9am, summer solstice

Hillshade_Noon (0 to 255 index) - Hillshade index at noon, summer solstice

Hillshade_3pm (0 to 255 index) - Hillshade index at 3pm, summer solstice

Horizontal_Distance_To_Fire_Points - Horz Dist to nearest wildfire ignition points

Wilderness_Area (4 binary columns, 0 = absence or 1 = presence) - Wilderness area designation

Soil_Type (40 binary columns, 0 = absence or 1 = presence) - Soil Type designation

Cover_Type (7 types, integers 1 to 7) - Forest Cover Type designation
source.90708d79: Slope has a unimodal distibution which is sligthly skewed. Most cover type has are in the area where there is less slope
source.2eeff6d9:
The violin plot shows two trends of distribution of cover type

Ponderosa pine, Douglas fir and Cottonwood have similar distribution so we can say that they belong to same wildnerness area

Aspen, Lodgepole pine, Spruce fir, Krummholz samples might be from different wildderness areas as the they have elongated distribution

source.16aecbcf:
The heatmp show the interaction between between the different factors. The features that shows same relation in all cover types :

Aspect - Hillshade_9am = -0.59

Aspect - Hillshade_3pm = 0.64

Slope - Hillshade_Noon = -0.61

Horizontal_Distance_To_Hydrology - Vertical_Distance_To_Hydrology = 0.65

Hillshade_9am - Hillshade_3pm = -0.78

Hillshade_Noon - Hillshade_3pm = 0.61
